Note:
Critical editions Schleich (1929)
XSchleich, Gustav. Sire Degarre. Heidelberg: Winter, 1929 (all mss); Carr (1923)
XCarr, Muriel B. “ Sir Degarre: A Middle English Metrical Romance Edited from the MS and Black Letter Texts with Introductory Chapters on the Filiation of Text and Phonology” Diss. Chicago, 1923 (all mss and prints).
_description: Sir Degare — 1076 verses in short couplets

BodRawPoe34.First Lines:
Lordyngges yff ye wyll herk & dwellOff noble men y wole yow
                    tell…
BodRawPoe34.Last Lines:
…Thus cam þe knyght outt of his careGod yff vs grace well
                    to fare
BodRawPoe34.Attributed Title: The lyff of Sir Degare both Curteys and ffre (f. 17v)

BodDou261.First Lines:
Syr Degore stode in study thanAnd thought he was a doughtye
                    man…
BodDou261.Last Lines:
…And that we vpon domes dayeMay come to the blysse that
                    lasteth aye
BodDou261.Note:
Transcript, c. 1564, of an early print; four fragments, 350
                    lines.
BodDou261.Attributed Title: Here endeth the treatyse of Syr Degore (f. 14v)

CULFf238.First Lines:
Lystenyþ lordynges gente & freY wyll yow telle of sir
                    degare…
CULFf238.Last Lines:
…Be fallyth many aman þorow chaun[ce]And comyþ
                    forþe in to vncerthe lede
CULFf238.Facsimiles:
McSparran,  Frances,  and  Pamela R. Robinson.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Cambridge University Library MS Ff.2.38.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.

BLEge2862.First Lines: …Wel ynorshid good and hendeÞat was no better in al þat ende…
BLEge2862.Last Lines: …When þe Parlement was plenereHe let crye ferre and nere…
BLEge2862.Note: Two fragments: lines 275-436 of London,  British Library Addit. 27879. Only two leaves survive, bound with Bevis of Hamptoun (3250). The text starts on f. 97 and continues on f. 95 (i.e., bound inverted).
BLEge2862.Attributed Title: Sir Degare (running titles split versos and rectos on each of the leaves).

BLAdd27879.Editions:
Hales,  John Wesley,  and  Frederick James Furnivall, eds.  
             Bishop Percy’s Folio Manuscript: Ballads and Romances.
         3 vols. London: Trübner, 1867-68: 3.16-48.

NLS1921.First Lines:
Kniȝtes þ[ ]ferli fele wolde fondeAnd sechen
                    auentures bi niȝt and daihou ȝhe miȝte here strengthe
                    asai…
NLS1921.Note:
1076 lines in this MS; text continues on stub, 84a, probably to
                        84arb.
